booksale. The money and checks
were plaood in Miss Dameron's
desk drawer at 5 p.m. Friday,

Though seventeen people have
keys to the office, Paul Stern of
APO said that "this was not an
inside job. Given five minutes and
a bobby pin, I could have opened it (the office)." In addition,
the desk drawer in which the
money was placed was not
locked.

to
Mr. Joseph
Geiger, head of Hopkins security, the robbery may have been
prevented by keeping the money
"under lock and key in a secure
area."

Comitission
Examined
(Continued from Page 1)
this study of the System and the
Commission concerned whether
or not the attempt to commit a
violation should constitute an
actual violation of the Honor
Code.
The Commission constitution
does not define a violation but the
basic guideline is "an attempt
to gain an unfair advantage over
the rest of the community." This
vague criterion results in the
question of where to draw the
line between attempt and intent
to cheat. Is a person guilty if he
plans to cheat but commits no
crime? Is the mental decision to
cheat actually equal to making
use of the physical material to
cheat?
The answers to these questions
have to be no. A person who does
not commit the act of gaining an
Unfair advantage is not gaining
an unfair advantage over the rest
of the community. The mere intention to gain an unfair advantage does no harm to the community. A boy who cheats on an
exam but does not hand in the
exam is not guilty of a crime.
He has not handed in the exam.
and this is the vital act which
commits him. Once the exam is
handed in, he is, if discovered,
guilty of gaining an unfair advantage.

Gaining An Unfair Advantage
Thus, a crime should be defined as the actual gaining of an
unfair advantage. The difference
here is that attempt should be
equated with act and not intent.
For no one should be convicted
of an honor violation for having
Merely the intention to cheat.
These are just a few of the
problems that I have encountered in my conversations with
Commission members, students
and the faculty. I do not intend
to imply that my solutions to
these problems are foolproof.
There are unquestionably two
sides to every issue and I must
admit that "the other side" was
often quite convincing. In many
cases, the problems I have discussed have been debated by the
Commission over a period of
months and sometimes years.
But without increased communication between the Commission
and the student body, those
problems will never be satisfactorily resolved.

Firstly the N.S.A. has been passing anti-government
resolutions for years. Just last summer at the national
convention the N.S.A. approved a measure condemning
the government for "misjudgements and miscalculations" leading to our involvement in the Vietnam war.
Hence unless the C.I.A. has been paying the student
piper with confederate money it has been getting a bad
deal. Perhaps the Agency has room in its budget for
support of the Goucher-Hopkins Bus? In any event it is
worth checking on.
It seems that the C.I.A. has supported N.S.A. overseas activity since the early 1950's. The subsidy was
covert because it was reasoned that public disclosure of
G.I.A. funding would have laid N.S.A. open to Communist criticism that the N.S.A. was an instrument of
the United States Government Fancy that. What happens
Now?
It was reasoned that Government support of the
N.S.A. was necessary to offset the influence of the Communist-dominated international student organizations
during the cold war period. The C.I.A. link was only
made known to one or two N.S.A. officials per year, many
of whom are now serving in high posts in the Government.
We can only agree with an open letter to L.B.J.
written by an assortment of congressmen that declared
that they were "appalled" and that it "represents an
unconscious extension of power by an agency of government over an institution outside its jurisdiction."
When confronted with the fact that the C.I.A.'s
support of N.S.A. was about to become public knowledge
the C.I.A. requested that N.S.A. deny the truth. To its
credit the N.S.A. refused. The News-Letter hopes that
N.S.A. (in many respects a worthy outfit) will survive
its poor judgement and get a good resale price on its
C.I.A.-supplied furniture.

A Gentle Affirmation
The plight of undergraduate education at Hopkins
examined with increasing intensity over the
been
has
past year, with the Long Range Planning Committee
and several student-administration forums searching for
concrete solutions to the inadequacies undermining the
current system.
In the recently published issue of the Vector,
Michael Fischer offers "a gentle critique" which raises
serious doubts as to the adequacy of the system itself.
To make his point, he distinguishes between the university and the college: "The accent in the one case is
on the expansion of human knowledge, and in the other
it is on th expansion of individual student horizons."
Despite claims that the goals of the uiversity are
pursued on the undergraduate level at Hopkins, it
should be obvious that, as Fischer points out, operating
on "the traditional American college system of requirements" is an anomaly at a true university, and that
herein lies the problem at Hopkins. His comparison of
JHU with the London School of Economics makes this
assertion all the more persuasive.
The nature of the comprehensive examination system, prevalent at Hopkins but not at the LSE, most clearly demonstrates Fischer's argument. Exams, he writes,
are "an effective levelling mechanism very well adapted to
the American ideal of the slow, plodding, unexceptional,
and solid pragmatist whose technical efficiency is first
class, but whose intellectual creativity does not challenge
the status quo." Memorization, not learning consequently, is the rule.
Fischer's concrete proposals for modifying the current system present an exciting vision for undergraduates at Hopkins. Greater emphasis on tutorials and individual research, made possible by concurrent deemphasis on restrictive requirements such as exams, are
two changes which would indicate a renewed committ'tient to the concept of the university education.
"We have the resources (i.e. the faculty)," he concludes; "all that is needed is the will." Fischer's article
deserves the attention of all those at Hopkins who are
concerned with bettering the conditions for undergraduate education at Homewood. If they can conclude that
Fischer's argument is indeed valid, but find that the will
is still lacking, it is imperative that they ask themselves
why.

TQ the Editors:
Elia Katz' review of Blow-Up
is, as are all Katz features, bad.
Not bad—Newsletter bad, where
there is no class and no taste
ard no life and no art—but bad
as in Katz bad. Why?
Because:
1) if the review was Intended
as satire (which it certainly did
not appear to be), it lacked any
parodical elements which, if

present, might have enabled it to
achieve such a purpose;
2) if the review was intended
as serious criticism, it rivaled
the editorials of the New York
Daily News for its extent of
journalistic talent;
3) Blow-Up was a remarkable
achievement, not merely within
the realm of the cinema, but as
a work of art. Katz certainly possesses the right to air his own
opinions of Blow-Up, but the reasons he cites for his opinions
abound in absurdity.

January 19, 1967
Dear Dr. Eisenhower,
We, the undersigned former
editors of the News-Letter, were
surprised and disheartened to
read in The Sun of January 16,
1967, of the temporary suspension
from the university of Melvin R.
Shuster and Henry J. Korn. We
are'aware that we lack explicit
information concerning their suspension and the history of the
relations between the News-Letter
and the administration during the
past academic year. Nevertheless,
we feel obliged to protest the
action which was taken against
them, and to clarify what we
have understood to be the position and role of the News-Letter
at Johns Hopkins.
According to The Sun. you sus-

pended the editors because the
News-Letter "carried a bitter
spoof of President Johnson." The
action against the students was
carried out "shortly after" you
saw the article. Unless other
factors were involved, it seems
to us that their suspension was
not only hasty, but also unwarranted. Even if the suspension
was temporary, it was an unfair
punishment, administered entirely without due process. Although
we are inclined to believe that
no campus organization has the
right to hold a "hearing" of the
News-Letter's editors, it seems to
us that if any group was to initiate an investigation, it should
have been the Student Council,
not the administration.
Your implication that the
News-Letter enjoys no freedom
of the press is supported by
neither its constitutional makeup
nor by its history. To support
your assertion that the NewsLetter is not an indepenant
journal, you were quoted in The
Sun as saying that the paper "is
subsidized by the university. It's
paid for by us. It's a house organ." Unless the institutional arrangement and constitution of
the News-Letter has changed
radically since we worked on it,
we must take exception to your
declaration. In the first place,
the News-Letter is not it house
organ, but an undergraduate student organization with its own

constitution and by-laws, an internal election procedure and an
editorial board to whom the editors have primary responsibility.
Secondly, the paper is not, to our
knowledge, supported or subsidized by university funds, as
such. During the seven years of
with
operations
News-Letter
which we are familiar, approximately one-quarter of the paper's
budget came from funds taken
out of student fees and allocated
by the Student Activities Commission with the approval of the
Dean of Students. The remainder
came from advertising income
and mail subscriptions.
The News-Letter, moreover, has
a long history of freedom of the
press. It has traditionally and
consistently behaved as a voice
representing the student body in
university affairs. At a time when
many American universities are
increasing the role which undergraduates have in running their
affairs, the action taken against
editors Shuster and Korn constitutes a big step backward. This
is ever more regretable in that
Hopkins could have become a
leader in this new trend as it has
been in so many other ways in
the past.
In addition to the lack of due
process afforded the editors and
the unjustified infringement upon
News-Letter freedom, we find another disquieting note in this incident. The action taken against
the News-Letter editors is another example of the unhealthy
relationship which has perennially existed between the student
body and the administration at
Johns Hopkins. There still seems
to be no satisfactory balance between administration restraint
from, and involvement in, student affairs. Once Again the students have discovered their administration only when they
transgressed unwritten rules and
blemished the name of the university. Otherwise, they would
have continued to find a sore
lack of interest and leadership.
Perhaps the question of responsibility should be thrown
back to those who accuse. The
News-Letter "spoof" may have
been in poor taste, but it was not
libelous. It makes us wonder
which was the more irresponsible
act—the publication of the article or the suspension of the students.

Beware of Wolfe
To the Editors:
As a regular reader of the
News-Letter, I wish to express
several comments and criticisms
on the form and content of the
paper. The letter was prompted,
amazingly enough, not by the
atrocious Man of the Year article, but by Baron Wormser's article on James Dickey.
From reading that article, and
Elia Katz's on the new theater,
it is obvious to me that your
columnists have thoroughly done
their Tom Wolfe homework. This
has irritated me all year, that
many of the critical features were
so heavily imitative of his work.
The reason Tom Wolfe made it
was that he was not imitative,
and not really imitable. He is a
child of the Pop culture, and developed his style to talk about
the mores of that society. James
Dickey, on the other hand is not
a Popist, and cannot be discussed
coherently in Wolfe's fashion.
Aside from the fact that I disagreed with the criticism of
Dickey's work, I was repulsed by
Wormser's second-hand style.
It is true that Dickey is simple,
apple pie, country boy, but that
is not a valid criticism of the
man or of his work. He is difficult perhaps, and somewhat too
self-consciously Dylan Thomasesque, but he can write superb

Five Driving For MAC Playoffs
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Its Southern Division Middle
Atlantic Conference title chances
jolted by last week's Drexel
debacle, the varsity basketball
team will attempt to keep alive
hopes for revenge by copping a
win at Dickinson tomorrow
night.
Serving as agent for those renewed aspirations is a revision
In MAC post-season procedure,
a move setting up playoffs between the first and second' place
teams of each division, with the
winners being nam:ed division
Champs and becoming league
representatives in the NCAA
small college tournament.
The Jays, all alone in second
place as of Tuesday, met Ursinus (6-4) in a crucial clash
two days ago, and, with two
league games besides that one
remaining, could conceivably be
passed by Muhlenburg (7-6),
Dickinson (6-6), Franklin and

NEWS
PAGE TEN

Marshall (5-5), or Washington
(4-5) (as well as Ursinus) in the
race for second place. Ursinus
and F&M have yet to meet
Drexel, on top at 9-2.
March 4 Playoff
The new post-season arrangement, replacing the traditional
inter-division four team tournament, should work to Drexel's
advantage, since by it the Dragons both avoid the stiffer Northern Division competition, and, as
is currently most likely, could
face Hopkins—ineligible for any
NCAA affair—in the March 4
playoff. The Jays are eliminated
from such events because of
Johns Hopkins' non-adherence
to the now-famous "1.6" rule,
and even by winning cannot prevent a Drexel trip to past-season
activity.
Dickinson, 7-7 overall, has
been an anomaly all year. Highly
rated at the season's opening,
the Red Devils have been fairly

unsuccessful despite a potent
offense (three starters around
seventeen points a game and a
79.3 team offensive mean) and
good sound height (a starting
five averaging 6-3 with the
presence of 6-9 frosh John
Detti).
Partial Explanations
Partial explanations for the
above might revolve around
porous defense
Dickinson's
which allows an output equal to
that of the offenSe--a.nd its rebounding weaknesses (a 56-52
defeoit in caroms per game after
nine games), but the Devils, who
start three lettermen, are a better club than their season performances would indicate and
could put a rapid halt to Hopkins' hopes.
The Jays get an opportunity
to seek revenge of a different
sort Wednesday, when they host
Loyola in a return encounter.

Comitission
Examined
(Continued from Page 1)
this study of the System and the
Commission concerned whether
or not the attempt to commit a
violation should constitute an
actual violation of the Honor
Code.
The Commission constitution
does not define a violation but the
basic guideline is "an attempt
to gain an unfair advantage over
the rest of the community." This
vague criterion results in the
question of where to draw the
line between attempt and intent
to cheat. Is a person guilty if he
plans to cheat but commits no
crime? Is the mental decision to
cheat actually equal to making
use of the physical material to
cheat?
The answers to these questions
have to be no. A person who does
not commit the act of gaining an
Unfair advantage is not gaining
an unfair advantage over the rest
of the community. The mere intention to gain an unfair advantage does no harm to the community. A boy who cheats on an
exam but does not hand in the
exam is not guilty of a crime.
He has not handed in the exam.
and this is the vital act which
commits him. Once the exam is
handed in, he is, if discovered,
guilty of gaining an unfair advantage.

unfair advantage. The difference
here is that attempt should be
equated with act and not intent.

Merely the intention to cheat.
These are just a few of the
problems that I have encountered in my conversations with
Commission members, students
and the faculty. I do not intend
to imply that my solutions to
these problems are foolproof.
There are unquestionably two
sides to every issue and I must
admit that "the other side" was
often quite convincing. In many
cases, the problems I have discussed have been debated by the
Commission over a period of
months and sometimes years.
But without increased communication between the Commission
and the student body, those
problems will never be satisfactorily resolved.

Firstly the N.S.A. has been passing anti-government
resolutions for years. Just last summer at the national
convention the N.S.A. approved a measure condemning
the government for "misjudgements and miscalculations" leading to our involvement in the Vietnam war.
Hence unless the C.I.A. has been paying the student
piper with confederate money it has been getting a bad
deal. Perhaps the Agency has room in its budget for
support of the Goucher-Hopkins Bus? In any event it is
worth checking on.
It seems that the C.I.A. has supported N.S.A. overseas activity since the early 1950's. The subsidy was
covert because it was reasoned that public disclosure of
G.I.A. funding would have laid N.S.A. open to Communist criticism that the N.S.A. was an instrument of
the United States Government Fancy that. What happens
Now?
It was reasoned that Government support of the
N.S.A. was necessary to offset the influence of the Communist-dominated international student organizations
during the cold war period. The C.I.A. link was only
made known to one or two N.S.A. officials per year, many
of whom are now serving in high posts in the Government.
We can only agree with an open letter to L.B.J.
written by an assortment of congressmen that declared
that they were "appalled" and that it "represents an
unconscious extension of power by an agency of government over an institution outside its jurisdiction."
When confronted with the fact that the C.I.A.'s
support of N.S.A. was about to become public knowledge
the C.I.A. requested that N.S.A. deny the truth. To its
credit the N.S.A. refused. The News-Letter hopes that
N.S.A. (in many respects a worthy outfit) will survive
its poor judgement and get a good resale price on its
C.I.A.-supplied furniture.

A Gentle Affirmation
The plight of undergraduate education at Hopkins
examined with increasing intensity over the
been
has
past year, with the Long Range Planning Committee
and several student-administration forums searching for
concrete solutions to the inadequacies undermining the
current system.
In the recently published issue of the Vector,
Michael Fischer offers "a gentle critique" which raises
serious doubts as to the adequacy of the system itself.
To make his point, he distinguishes between the university and the college: "The accent in the one case is
on the expansion of human knowledge, and in the other
it is on th expansion of individual student horizons."
Despite claims that the goals of the uiversity are
pursued on the undergraduate level at Hopkins, it
should be obvious that, as Fischer points out, operating
on "the traditional American college system of requirements" is an anomaly at a true university, and that
herein lies the problem at Hopkins. His comparison of
JHU with the London School of Economics makes this
assertion all the more persuasive.
The nature of the comprehensive examination system, prevalent at Hopkins but not at the LSE, most clearly demonstrates Fischer's argument. Exams, he writes,
are "an effective levelling mechanism very well adapted to
the American ideal of the slow, plodding, unexceptional,
and solid pragmatist whose technical efficiency is first
class, but whose intellectual creativity does not challenge
the status quo." Memorization, not learning consequently, is the rule.
Fischer's concrete proposals for modifying the current system present an exciting vision for undergraduates at Hopkins. Greater emphasis on tutorials and individual research, made possible by concurrent deemphasis on restrictive requirements such as exams, are
two changes which would indicate a renewed committ'tient to the concept of the university education.
"We have the resources (i.e. the faculty)," he concludes; "all that is needed is the will." Fischer's article
deserves the attention of all those at Hopkins who are
concerned with bettering the conditions for undergraduate education at Homewood. If they can conclude that
Fischer's argument is indeed valid, but find that the will
is still lacking, it is imperative that they ask themselves
why.

TQ the Editors:
Elia Katz' review of Blow-Up
is, as are all Katz features, bad.
Not bad—Newsletter bad, where
there is no class and no taste
ard no life and no art—but bad
as in Katz bad. Why?
Because:
1) if the review was Intended
as satire (which it certainly did
not appear to be), it lacked any
parodical elements which, if

present, might have enabled it to
achieve such a purpose;
2) if the review was intended
as serious criticism, it rivaled
the editorials of the New York
Daily News for its extent of
journalistic talent;
3) Blow-Up was a remarkable
achievement, not merely within
the realm of the cinema, but as
a work of art. Katz certainly possesses the right to air his own
opinions of Blow-Up, but the reasons he cites for his opinions
abound in absurdity.

January 19, 1967
Dear Dr. Eisenhower,
We, the undersigned former
editors of the News-Letter, were
surprised and disheartened to
read in The Sun of January 16,
1967, of the temporary suspension
from the university of Melvin R.
Shuster and Henry J. Korn. We
are'aware that we lack explicit
information concerning their suspension and the history of the
relations between the News-Letter
and the administration during the
past academic year. Nevertheless,
we feel obliged to protest the
action which was taken against
them, and to clarify what we
have understood to be the position and role of the News-Letter
at Johns Hopkins.
According to The Sun. you sus-

pended the editors because the
News-Letter "carried a bitter
spoof of President Johnson." The
action against the students was
carried out "shortly after" you
saw the article. Unless other
factors were involved, it seems
to us that their suspension was
not only hasty, but also unwarranted. Even if the suspension
was temporary, it was an unfair
punishment, administered entirely without due process. Although
we are inclined to believe that
no campus organization has the
right to hold a "hearing" of the
News-Letter's editors, it seems to
us that if any group was to initiate an investigation, it should
have been the Student Council,
not the administration.
Your implication that the
News-Letter enjoys no freedom
of the press is supported by
neither its constitutional makeup
nor by its history. To support
your assertion that the NewsLetter is not an indepenant
journal, you were quoted in The
Sun as saying that the paper "is
subsidized by the university. It's
paid for by us. It's a house organ." Unless the institutional arrangement and constitution of
the News-Letter has changed
radically since we worked on it,
we must take exception to your
declaration. In the first place,
the News-Letter is not it house
organ, but an undergraduate student organization with its own

constitution and by-laws, an internal election procedure and an
editorial board to whom the editors have primary responsibility.
Secondly, the paper is not, to our
knowledge, supported or subsidized by university funds, as
such. During the seven years of
with
operations
News-Letter
which we are familiar, approximately one-quarter of the paper's
budget came from funds taken
out of student fees and allocated
by the Student Activities Commission with the approval of the
Dean of Students. The remainder
came from advertising income
and mail subscriptions.
The News-Letter, moreover, has
a long history of freedom of the
press. It has traditionally and
consistently behaved as a voice
representing the student body in
university affairs. At a time when
many American universities are
increasing the role which undergraduates have in running their
affairs, the action taken against
editors Shuster and Korn constitutes a big step backward. This
is ever more regretable in that
Hopkins could have become a
leader in this new trend as it has
been in so many other ways in
the past.
In addition to the lack of due
process afforded the editors and
the unjustified infringement upon
News-Letter freedom, we find another disquieting note in this incident. The action taken against
the News-Letter editors is another example of the unhealthy
relationship which has perennially existed between the student
body and the administration at
Johns Hopkins. There still seems
to be no satisfactory balance between administration restraint
from, and involvement in, student affairs. Once Again the students have discovered their administration only when they
transgressed unwritten rules and
blemished the name of the university. Otherwise, they would
have continued to find a sore
lack of interest and leadership.
Perhaps the question of responsibility should be thrown
back to those who accuse. The
News-Letter "spoof" may have
been in poor taste, but it was not
libelous. It makes us wonder
which was the more irresponsible
act—the publication of the article or the suspension of the students.

To the Editors:
As a regular reader of the
News-Letter, I wish to express
several comments and criticisms
on the form and content of the
paper. The letter was prompted,
amazingly enough, not by the
atrocious Man of the Year article, but by Baron Wormser's article on James Dickey.
From reading that article, and
Elia Katz's on the new theater,
it is obvious to me that your
columnists have thoroughly done
their Tom Wolfe homework. This
has irritated me all year, that
many of the critical features were
so heavily imitative of his work.
The reason Tom Wolfe made it
was that he was not imitative,
and not really imitable. He is a
child of the Pop culture, and developed his style to talk about
the mores of that society. James
Dickey, on the other hand is not
a Popist, and cannot be discussed
coherently in Wolfe's fashion.
Aside from the fact that I disagreed with the criticism of
Dickey's work, I was repulsed by
Wormser's second-hand style.
It is true that Dickey is simple,
apple pie, country boy, but that
is not a valid criticism of the
man or of his work. He is difficult perhaps, and somewhat too
self-consciously Dylan Thomasesque, but he can write superb
poetry. He is not a symbolist, or
an imagist, rather a sensual poet
who merely enjoys the textures
of life, and has valuable things
to say about the way people live

Five Driving For MAC Playoffs
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Its Southern Division Middle
Atlantic Conference title chances
jolted by last week's Drexel
debacle, the varsity basketball
team will attempt to keep alive
hopes for revenge by copping a
win at Dickinson tomorrow
night.
Serving as agent for those renewed aspirations is a revision
In MAC post-season procedure,
a move setting up playoffs between the first and second' place
teams of each division, with the
winners being nam:ed division
Champs and becoming league
representatives in the NCAA
small college tournament.
The Jays, all alone in second
place as of Tuesday, met Ursinus (6-4) in a crucial clash
two days ago, and, with two
league games besides that one
remaining, could conceivably be
passed by Muhlenburg (7-6),
Dickinson (6-6), Franklin and

NEWS
PAGE TEN

Marshall (5-5), or Washington
(4-5) (as well as Ursinus) in the
race for second place. Ursinus
and F&M have yet to meet
Drexel, on top at 9-2.
March 4 Playoff
The new post-season arrangement, replacing the traditional
inter-division four team tournament, should work to Drexel's
advantage, since by it the Dragons both avoid the stiffer Northern Division competition, and, as
is currently most likely, could
face Hopkins—ineligible for any
NCAA affair—in the March 4
playoff. The Jays are eliminated
from such events because of
Johns Hopkins' non-adherence
to the now-famous "1.6" rule,
and even by winning cannot prevent a Drexel trip to past-season
activity.
Dickinson, 7-7 overall, has
been an anomaly all year. Highly
rated at the season's opening,
the Red Devils have been fairly

unsuccessful despite a potent
offense (three starters around
seventeen points a game and a
79.3 team offensive mean) and
good sound height (a starting
five averaging 6-3 with the
presence of 6-9 frosh John
Detti).
Partial Explanations
Partial explanations for the
above might revolve around
porous defense
Dickinson's
which allows an output equal to
that of the offenSe--a.nd its rebounding weaknesses (a 56-52
defeoit in caroms per game after
nine games), but the Devils, who
start three lettermen, are a better club than their season performances would indicate and
could put a rapid halt to Hopkins' hopes.
The Jays get an opportunity
to seek revenge of a different
sort Wednesday, when they host
Loyola in a return encounter.
